thread.title: NatWest and RBS suffer hacker attack that leaves customers unable to access accounts
thread.title_full: NatWest and RBS suffer hacker attack that leaves customers unable to access accounts

title: NatWest and RBS suffer hacker attack that leaves customers unable to access accounts
text:
NatWest and RBS suffer hacker attack that leaves customers unable to access accounts NatWest and RBS suffer hacker attack that leaves customers unable to access accounts NatWest and RBS customers were unable to access their accounts today, after the bank suffered a malicious attack by online criminals. PUBLISHED: 16:00, Fri, Jul 31, 2015 | UPDATED: 16:31, Fri, Jul 31, 2015 GETTY NatWest users are having problems with their accounts 
Affected customers went online to complain that they couldn't get on to accounts online or through apps this morning and that expected payments had not reached their accounts. 
Users were told that the bank was investigating problems and apologised for the inconvenience. 
But the group, which includes Ulster brands, has now confirmed that the disruption had been the result of a cyber assault.An unknown source brought the bank's system to its knees, by flooding the website with traffic in a so-called Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attack. 
NatWest and RBS systems are now back up and running and the bank has moved to make assurances that customer details or accounts were not put at risk. 
A spokesperson said: "The issues that some customers experienced accessing online banking this morning was due to a surge in internet traffic deliberately directed at the website. 
"At no time was there any risk to customers. 
"Customers experienced issues for around 50 minutes and this has now been resolved. 
"We apologise for the inconvenience caused." 
After the attack, users who were still experiencing problems were advised that deleting and re-installing the app should help to resolve remaining issues. 
Experts said that the attack could have been the result of someone who holds a grudge with the company. Related articles The big name banks losing the most customers 
Computer security expert Graham Cluley said: "You don't need to be a hacker mastermind to orchestrate a distributed denial-of-service attacks (DDoS) attack. 
"It's well within the capabilities of many online criminals, who can take order hijacked PCs to bombard a website with traffic."Sometimes DDoS attacks are launched with blackmail in mind ("pay us cash, or your website won't come back") but often they can be orchestrated by hacktivists who might have a grudge against a particular business or industry, rather than with a financial motive."The good news is that a DDoS attack is just disruptive - it doesn't mean that the security of a website has been breached, or that your personal data might be at risk. 
"It's the equivalent of a large crowd standing outside the doors of a business, preventing you from going in to buy anything." 
Today's attack is just the latest in a line of technical problems for the bank, but this is the first time that it has admitted problems have been the result of an online crime. 
Last month a glitch meant that customer's payments went 'missing' and red-faced bosses apologised for IT systems. 
And 18 months ago, customers were unable to access accounts or withdraw money. 
In response to the news that systems were down today, Twitter user Juliette Thomas today wrote: "Again? On payday of all days. Your systems are useless and frustrating!" Can't access online banking or withdraw? Is something down @NatWest_Help ? — Laura Underdown (@lauralovesblog) July 31, 2015 @NatWest_Help Can't log in to online banking — Necia Rogers (@Neeksthephotog) July 31, 2015 @NatWest_Help online banking not working what is the issue please?
